review_title: Unique company - successful financially and takes good care of its people
pros: I like working here. It’s successful financially and thus relatively stable and can make long-term decisions. It does interesting and meaningful things for its customers, and I think the company takes good care of its people.

pros: The people here are great. No egos, everyone is friendly, willing to share info/help out. Our offices are also in good locations, so fairly easy to get in and out of work. And the work is good - strong company mission everyone can get behind.

Don't think they hired a change or M&A consultant and tried to do everything internally which has meant a lot of crossed wires and lack of clarity. Benefits are so-so. pros: ExpressVPN has a great company mission, and the people I've had the opportunity to work with have all been fantastic. There is a culture of cross-team collaboration, meaning I get to work with people I wouldn't usually and learn immensely from them. Because the company is relatively small (in the grand scheme of things), it provides flat hierarchy and people feel empowered to speak up, contribute, and make a difference.
cons: For a internet/tech company, the benefits aren't super great. There isn't a hybrid working structure (only one day WFH at the moment), but there are flexible hours and unlimited sick days. Compensation is pretty much mid-market, and health insurance is sufficient but not as comprehensive as previous companies I've worked at. The team I'm on has pretty decent hours though, so I'm not doing a lot of overtime, which is good !

review_title: I feel lucky to be here, I can't get enough of it.
pros:
When I was in early stages of interviewing and considering working at ExpressVPN, I honestly didn't know very much about VPNs in general or much about how they work. But the company was looking to fill a role inside their Marketing department which very closely suited my skills and experience, so I was definitely drawn to it.

The interview process was the longest I've experienced in my career so far, but honestly not by much. I had several rounds and met many different people of different seniority levels and on top of that I also had to submit some assignments, in order to really prove my ability. This did seem like quite a bit of work initially, but it completely makes sense in order for a company to really know for sure if a person is the right fit and the chemistry between team members would work out. 

I also asked for a little more time to complete my assignments as I told the recruiter at ExpressVPN that I had a lot of work on my plate at that time and I wanted to do the tasks the right way. The company was very cool about it, which was awesome. 

I'll also add that the whole experience with each person that I met through the interview, (especially the main recruiter who was with me every step), were so warm and welcoming and I've never felt so strongly like they really wanted me to get the job! So that was such a delight and really was a great experience. Even if I hadn't gotten the role I would have definitely learnt some valuable things from the interview process here.

That being said I did accept the offer and haven't looked back. The company is so well organized and everything is so clear in terms of what is expected of you and how to communicate and execute on projects. 

I've worked at different companies in the past that had just 6 employees, and I've been in ones that had over 10,000 globally. And none of them have had such a lid on making sure everyone communicates effectively, everyone feels comfortable, that when teams which are made up of people with completely different skills and backgrounds, they are all managed extremely well and have the resources and support they need to get things done.

It's hard to put into words honestly when everything just feels right, but I think it's great place to work.
cons: There are a lot of processes and procedures to learn, but it's not difficult.
